jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

13E69D8531214AD58F4C6BBE1052A30F.description: Explore poetry as a form of dramatic expression.

E6537425EE2F4147B145E7FD705D6854.description: Experiment with dramatic forms used in the Middle Ages.

171513948421458F8C48AEBF52F7D59A.description: Explore cowboy poetry as a form of dramatic expression.

A42839AB20D84A22B16E3B970130D0F5.description: Discuss knowledge that First Nations, Metis, and Inuit can share through storytelling.

2FAF17DED07E402589C38F1EE0E70038.description: Investigate storytelling in a variety of Alberta cultures or contexts.

544AA77824BC406FA914D9CB78667115.description: Demonstrate how artistic roles and responsibilities contribute to a sense of community

C5528F3226B14DC2A4C64EA695AD0622.description: Participate in drama as members of an artistic community

F73EF1CD70054537BFABD886EE497B99.description: Culture was revealed through dramatic performances during the Middle Ages.

40D661BD7C1241B08429496DF0B5265E.description: Drama and storytelling in Alberta can reflect the culture of those who came before us and those who live here now.

6EDF030CE41A4DB0B0E1CDB3A83D4F8B.description: The culture of an artistic community is about shared ways of being together and reaching common goals.

BE682DEA18FC457990B918F9A013BDBC.description: When communities unite through the arts, culture can be learned.

94E0F418F3994F15B499AAC2D5EAB503.description: Rumi (1207-1273) was an important Muslim poet who influenced many cultures and whose poetry is still recited today

30D6CDE780FA4E28B509782AF86D6EF1.description: Theatrical performances in medieval Islamic cultures included poetry recitations and storytelling that occurred outside.

ED187CB77E1D4F3D9759B1E94F39D58C.description: Performances in medieval Europe included various kinds of drama, such as stories based on the Bible interludes, which are short comical plays farces based on unlikely situations

CCF202A7297A44CFBA0822763892627B.description: Some performances in medieval Europe happened inside churches, while others were held outside, in towns and villages, for everyone to see

B8065B70F59548208FB8730419DA3ADC.description: Drama in the Middle Ages used various dramatic forms, including mime acrobatics juggling singing (minstrels) storytelling shadow puppetry narrative drama

DB9F2C72652D4C0FBFB12F7CD587A238.description: Performers may have been part of a membership called a guild and travelled and performed throughout various communities

B8D7ABBBDE644258A76329EAABBB2540.description: Performers throughout the Middle Ages often used their art to transfer and preserve their skills and traditions

237ED89D3475420DAB9D017E1F208965.description: Cowboy poetry is a form of performance that grew out of the culture of cowboys telling stories

4A3F67D1C14C413DAF0D0D6E9FCE740D.description: Communities in Alberta may share their cultural traditions through a variety of formal or informal dramatic practices, such as readings, recitations, and storytelling.

80059D70ACFE4C008CA120C92C92E192.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit knowledge shared through storytelling can share teachings and histories communicate values and beliefs show gratitude and reverence demonstrate reciprocity reflect spirituality contribute to healing guide and direct choices and actions

7B9895439C534A92888483588F65A4C9.description: The culture of an artistic community can support the caring and respectful inclusion of all participants

3D02A881F6A14330A1452BC222A56088.description: Culture can be enhanced when members of a drama community participate, communicate, engage, and share responsibilities.

CAA3144A2E6F4DC4B12BE1E6158B5C4D.description: Students relate how culture is reflected in drama and storytelling across time and place

7970B909A6F64ABA8936EE3AE11B79AE.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate.

1066DD70DEA544CCB963C66B7CC1AAB7.description: Participate as a performer and as an audience member in drama.

B5F76AC5A1DE4F628BD83CB73743D66A.description: Apply creative processes when creating a narrative.

B42477E7F28045479B1750DE7EFEB854.description: Respond to verbal cues given by a director when rehearsing a narrative.

41ECA4248F51401691CF40FF86151F2A.description: Collaborate with others when creating and representing a narrative in drama

700FCC91F262446CBBFCF9B12D560B61.description: Experiment with various ways to use the voice to represent a character within a narrative.

269E97E857DF4548BC96DEAB71D027C2.description: Perform a narrative from a personal point of view.

8878B260773E4551A95AF713AEDF2039.description: Express a narrative from a point of view of another character or characters

43119FAAD6294FD79ADC5B58BEDFF777.description: Explore various ways to structure a narrative.

783211D5E71243629F241C9E6703450E.description: Choose an inspiration for a narrative.

4DEAC3A25975464BACA31D044DC62302.description: A narrative in drama can be shaped by the performer(s), the director, and the audience.

3D12D2153FAB40DF8B870D26570E76E9.description: The way in which dramatic processes are applied can communicate perspectives, ideas, and feelings

A283B310587C40E595B1FF4D07CC145A.description: A narrative can communicate points of view or perspectives of an individual or group.

7426E73F17394418960396FB685E75DA.description: A narrative in drama can be factual or fictitious

B576F8CF19B044B28DE078322C2D01E0.description: A narrative in drama can be illustrated as a partial or whole representation.

03874E4403F640C8A08250F244755C02.description: Working with an ensemble can develop skills that can be transferred to other areas of learning.

6386E2513EFD497FACEBC18557E1143F.description: Creative processes, including rehearsal, can help a performer refine expression of a narrative in drama

53108E5E755A430E823ED3EC9DD9BB28.description: A director can shape a narrative by giving verbal cues that guide the performer or ensemble

A9DC9DD6080C46D49A4117426E731382.description: Vocal production and body movement may need to be adjusted when performing for an audience.

45E485D4B39247DEAB07A13793E3B2E2.description: Dramatic forms, including readers' theatre and choral speech, are prepared scripts that can be used to tell a narrative.

8DCDF5D7035D48208C378C1663FA5F47.description: Blocking can help clarify positioning and movement of actors when performing a narrative.

0E14C8039A0449CE9BF3B5FDF4397666.description: A narrative can be communicated non-verbally through the use of movements, as seen in mime or tableau

AE204D724C63407F9BABE80F2EF9B820.description: Vocal expression can change the meaning of words expressed in a narrative.

04A860CF64494FE7B67F0788BA3958A7.description: A performer can make experimental or informed artistic choices to shape a narrative, including the choice of costumes props sets lights voice movement

623C9179DF564B69B1E6385B3A3CE472.description: Status communicates the relationships between two characters.

DA87EFFD3737473E8919056522CD53E7.description: Communication of a narrative can feature a character's intention, status, or feelings through role play.

F508A16D674A46699CD19B499ED65522.description: Empathy can influence how a narrative is communicated

22D5A22A15524CCA8315A8483CC9FE24.description: Points of view or perspectives can reflect feelings, experiences, and culture.

622CF34C78744C29AFF32C05C8A4A6C1.description: Inspiration for a narrative may come from stories documentaries different forms of media conversations imagination people or characters

8F1C102B408142078139D674E8A8BC11.description: Dramatic forms can give structure to a narrative

30AC22AA00CD4374B40EF70A2A9CCFF9.description: A narrative in drama can be structured in a variety of ways, including a theme a vignette - a short episode a scene an act an entire play

387F744BD54348D3BCDF7DA1B95480AC.description: A narrative in drama may or may not represent a sequence of events in the order in which they happened

5D604082DB38402D89894AB661C88E4D.description: Students employ narrative as a structure for organizing, creating, and presenting dramatizations.

CC57389AA1254920A63AE357122D6F82.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

6416E79BFEE84AD88D9AEA792CACE538.description: Participate in warm-up activities that prepare the body and voice for expression

5BE182926DB4408598EDD6563CD5140A.description: Evaluate projection of the voice when speaking in a variety of spaces.

84B8B7C3F8B9460581B74C1AEB74E184.description: Use techniques for the safe production and projection of the voice through a variety of drama activities.

331864C4E6324F9FAC9C8A2B588CAB6C.description: Discuss how speech can be affected by how the body and voice are used.

90BE6733F00A4905B5749580A43D13CC.description: Demonstrate how the voice contributes to a variety of dramatic situations

53B1BE039B494C71B8A6B6996C8AD72C.description: Use dramatic forms to support expressive use of the voice.

0B69BC6FDA4D4D52A2B4C4E41EE02569.description: Explore how changes in vocal quality can influence words and meaning.

9E53C4BED7EE449BB3B563076A719C44.description: Explore how combining the body and voice can contribute to character development

913A226BC09F4B7C9D95C4F1A19E9236.description: Explore how blocking can contribute to presentations in drama.

E45B9C22C2FE4CF48DD30CF0824C283A.description: Experiment with how characters react in different situations.

E25B7ACA79D24406A36B366CF19F7667.description: Analyze different ways of moving alone and with others.

F939CD0554BE429794C94CB1E6804571.description: Sustain body actions in the representation of character

67920DB4C3E545929744431811514DEC.description: Experiment with various dramatic forms to support individual and group expression.

5D1F4DA3A801460BBC7200531D1BCD7C.description: Experiment with role play in the development of a character.

8EBA1E568AC6434FA46D762790E5331A.description: Discuss how empathy and perspectives can guide character development.

8AEC53C326E04C91ADE9F71341E804E0.description: The voice is dependent on the body.

943D353531884FF787B4C7048300E850.description: The voice can communicate intent in the way that it is used on its own or when paired with body movements.

4B72A26731724AC8895A23106FF12CE7.description: Expression can be enhanced when the body and voice are combined

3913E45518A34913B5F524DE515E58ED.description: The body can be analyzed through movement, space, and relationships.

67A4011EDD1D4DB1B42453DAE38DB231.description: What a person is thinking and how they are feeling can influence how they portray a character.

9D88E9E777D04083A77DD12E130D1326.description: The body and mind connect thinking and feeling to make meaning

EE321B5E69DB40268B09AC586C05BBF4.description: Voice can be communicated through sign language and gesture

6EC10BB86EFB4A158C98FA5F2901EA37.description: The voice is the combination of breath and the vibration of vocal cords

0A886CCF310E46F69CADD8D75FC5CD19.description: Safe projection of the voice includes appropriate breath support, volume, and control

3C673621FB8C44A79A314504D0FCBB4B.description: The body and the voice function optimally when warmed up and exercised

390DF4B440F742B0AE3D4FAF75CC9144.description: Voice production relies on body positioning.

50441CE20156413E9AE62B2B389F2DB4.description: The diaphragm is a muscle that supports vocal health and production and projection of the voice

961A53C05CD64D7CB77CA57D79441298.description: The voice has many qualities that make it identifiable (timbre) and can include shouting, whispering, singing, and speaking

A6902FD1F06F4F5FA3219520EB8D6FCD.description: Soundscapes express environments, moods, and scenarios through the use of tone, breath, volume, and vocal sound effects

868007DF562145D7B6BADD79E819C9D2.description: Words and meaning can change based on tone volume timing pace rhythm

69F78B808DA142D5BC114EDEBAE1F510.description: Readers' theatre skills help develop the ability to communicate from a prepared script

DF121761B1E24B32971D1BCECFDAB904.description: Radio play is an auditory dramatic form that features music, dialogue, and sound effects to highlight characters and story

337EE1DAABCD4F25B52EE71F31A595BE.description: Speaking skills can help develop vocal expression through exploration of tone, volume, and timing

67543401C5324B46AD37AC6BE23E3742.description: Body expression has a relationship to other characters space situations props voice

22F68D3755BA44D6BA5A27342037FE4C.description: Blocking involves body movement and positioning that contributes to the staging of presentations in drama.

CE1CE92CEC4447688D1884450278809C.description: A situation in drama has structure that includes time and place.

EDB1290D152B425E8E6A91C7E95240B9.description: A character is developed through the body and in relation to the dramatic role and situation

D51D1A3B9CA7466DBEF410BA83D5313F.description: Group drama is a dramatic form used to collaboratively build a dramatization through the acceptance of ideas

C070A244A21A4A0A9B9B9C636D5C4007.description: Imagination and prior knowledge can guide role play

8BD082E88B224654B287AE920725D6C6.description: Role-playing skills support the ability to use the body to take on the attitude of another individual assume the physical attributes of another individual empathize the situation of another individual

3619753DF8A940748CFB53A2CD366E2B.description: Empathy is the ability to share the feelings of another individual.

FBBDCE1517FD475A9120E8A92D69D9AD.description: Students relate the voice and the body as a means to portray roles, characters, and situations.

9A28A7A2ED784962819E8494DFBFD70B.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
